column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=React when Your Child Goes Missing
#Text=Although true abduction cases are very rare sometimes you may find yourself in a situation where you ca n't find your child .
#Text=In this moment it 's important to stay calm , and be prepared to get help immediately .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Make important calls immediately .
#Text=Dial 911 as soon as you 're sure your child is not in the immediate area .
#Text=Legally , they are required to enter their information into the National Crime Information Center ( NCIC) 's Missing person file right away .
#Text=Officers may also put out a BOLO ( Be on the lookout ) or AMBER alert if they feel they are in danger .
#Text=Be prepared to share information .
#Text=You may be panicking and unable to think but it 's important to give police as much about your child as you can , so they have an easier time finding them .
#Text=Be prepared to give your child 's :
#Text=Full name
#Text=Height and weight
#Text=Age and birthdate
#Text=Clothing child was wearing
#Text=Features such as glasses , scars , birthmarks , etc.
#Text=Names , addresses , and numbers of child 's friends/family
#Text=Frequently visited spots
#Text=Any health issues
#Text=A picture , so try to find several recent photos that clearly display
#Text=Look in your immediate area .
#Text=Begin searching around where you last saw your child .
#Text=On and under all beds , piles of laundry , around and inside vehicles , inside washer and dryers .
#Text=Anywhere a small child could climb inside .
#Text=Notify the business .
#Text=If you 're in a store or other business notify a manager or guard immediately .
#Text=Most stores will follow a Code Adam protocol where all employees will help look and lock down the store to ensure the child does n't leave .
#Text=Look for digital clues .
#Text=If a child is old enough to have a phone or online presence , look through recent Google searches , messages , and emails or ask police to .
#Text=They may have left some clue as to where they were going .
#Text=Keep yourself available .
#Text=You may want to start pounding the pavement yourself , but it is strongly advised to focus on gathering information to give to police .
#Text=Police may want to search the child 's room and take several items as evidence .
#Text=They may also need an item of clothing from your child for the search .
#Text=Keep your phone line open .
#Text=In case police , your child , or someone else attempts to call you try to keep a phone line open .
#Text=Call someone to be with you .

#Text=In this stressful time if you 're alone you may want someone to help you out with giving information to the police or remembering information given to you , or just to provide some probably much needed comfort .
#Text=Inform the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children .
#Text=After calling local police enlist the help of the NCMEC by calling 1-800-THE-LOST ( 1-800-843-5678 ) , a non profit dedicated to helping children .
#Text=They can help you out greatly in the search .
#Text=Prevent it from happening .
#Text=The best way is to prevent it from happening in the first place .

#Text=Easier said than done sometimes but research or ask your local police for ways to locate a missing child such as phone locator apps , alarms on doors and windows , security cameras in and around the house , whistles/portable alarms , and other security measures can be great deterrents for both would be offenders and sly children trying to sneak out !
